Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing Argumentation with Social Media: Supporting Teacher Professional

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This exploratory proposal is researching and developing professional learning activities to help high school teachers use available and emerging social media to teach scientific argumentation. The project responds to the growing emphasis on scientific argumentation in new standards. Participants include a team of ninth and tenth grade Life Science teachers collaborating as co-researchers with project staff in a design study to develop one socially mediated science unit. It also produces strategies, tools and on-line materials to support teachers' development of the pedagogical, content, and technological knowledge needed to integrate emerging technologies into science instruction. This project focuses on the flexible social media sites such as Facebook, Twitter and Instagram that students frequently use in their everyday lives. Research questions explore the technology of social media and the pedagogy needed to support student engagement in scientific argumentation. The Year Three pilot analyses provide data on the professional learning model. The project provides a basis for scale-up with this instructional and professional learning model to other core science content, cross-cutting themes, and STEM practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Findings: The first three project research goals focused on better understanding the technological, pedagogical, and content knowledge that is needed to support teachers as they facilitate student practice of scientific argumentation using social media in high school Biology classrooms. Goal One explored what technological knowledge and technological professional learning supports are needed to facilitate teacher use of social media. Teacher interviews and survey findings showed that the best technological professional learning supports involved over-the-shoulder coaching, learning from peers, trial and error, and identifying strategies that best engage teachers and how they can be used to authenticate their learning experiences.  

Through project exploration of the NGSS and the creation of a curricular unit, teacher-researchers had an opportunity to analyze their own pedagogy, further develop their philosophies as science educators, and determine how they needed to change their teaching in order to be more student-centered and practice-based.  At the end of the project all the teacher-researchers felt that, as a result of the peer-based professional learning, they made changes in their pedagogical and content knowledge, and that there was more work to be done.  

Findings showed the use of social media for professional learning to be highly productive and successful. Teachers used the project Facebook group to plan lessons, problem solve instructional issues, and dialogue about areas of concern or struggle. They also used the space to share resources, propose new ideas, and grapple with the content. Facebook served as a safe community for collaborative learning, while also allowing for one-to-one mentoring through individual messaging. Findings showed that social media can serve as a professional learning environment, especially when paired with face-to-face meetings and frequent Skype calls.

The last three research goals focused on student practice of argumentation via social media.  The collaborative unit designed with university faculty and teacher-researchers emphasized how best to incorporate both argumentation and social media into secondary Biology instruction. Quantitative results showed that students in the treatment classrooms, as a result of their work in the Inheritance and Variation of Traits unit, felt confident in their ability to make scientific claims. They scored significantly higher on a test of scientific argumentation than the students in the comparison classrooms and became familiar with the components needed to make a good argument. Qualitative results showed that, while students have specific preferences for the types and uses of social media, they recognize the importance of digital citizenship and the need to support their claims with evidence from credible sources.

Intellectual Merit: This work described the use of specific strategies and methods to support higher-order thinking on a digital platform. Children and youth will continue to be highly engaged in the digital world and showing them how to perform productively and for learning was a key contribution of this grant. The unit of study produced through this work serves as a model for the use of argumentation vocabulary and practice while offering field-tested solutions for engaging students in the practice via social media. It should be noted, however, that the teacher-researchers in this project struggled with releasing some of their content to make room for depth of understanding and the accompanying instructional materials offer strategies to support this transition for other science educators.

Broader Impact: The practice of argumentation, making claims, using evidence and reasoning can be found in all of the Common Core State Standards (CCSS) from language arts to mathematics. Developing students to be critical thinkers, informed consumers, and responsible digital citizens is an important component of college and career readiness. During focus groups, several students offered anecdotes of how they now question the authority and evidence of various media claims, including those in radio advertisements, television broadcasts, and Internet publications. The importance of digital citizenship was a key take-away for project students. For example, understanding that what is posted on social media stays on social media forever, serves as an incentive for them to be careful with their posts. Students also referenced how they pay better attention to their writing for assignments when they know that it will be seen on social media and not just by the teacher.

Students must, in the short term, succeed on high-stakes assessments and understand the application of argumentation in science. In the long term, and most importantly, citizens must independently be able to apply reasoning to claims or statements made to convince others about issues in everyday life, especially in evaluating the myriad of scientific claims and arguments that bombard our society daily.  Engaging in scientific argumentation and authentic learning tasks will potentially motivate students to pursue additional education and careers in STEM, but also encourage all students, no matter their future to be more thoughtful, resourceful, and critical consumers of information.
